item.title: The Art of the American Nickname
item.dc:creator: Sarojini Seupersad
item.description: To most people I encounter, I have a wonderfully (or not so wonderfully) difficult ethnic name. For those of you who’ve never heard (of) my name and don’t know how to say it, it sounds something like this: Sa ‘roo ja nee. Got it? Maybe? Take your time, practice a little, I’ll wait. My name [...]

But there are some times that I need to yank that old paper and glue tome off its bookshelf and turn some pages. A few [...]

item.title: A trip to the Bastille — Grenoble, France.
item.dc:creator: Elise Hahn Photography
item.description: Pearce and I finally did something today that we suspect most people do on their first day in Grenoble — we took the cable car high above the city to the ancient defensive fortress, or Bastille. Talk about a picture-perfect view! I must add, with the exception of getting caught in a cable car on [...]
item.content:encoded:
Pearce and I finally did something today that we suspect most people do on their first day in Grenoble — we took the cable car high above the city to the ancient defensive fortress, or Bastille. Talk about a picture-perfect view!

I must add, with the exception of getting caught in a cable car on the way up with a young boy who had the worst BO we’ve smelt in a while (did I mention these cars are fully sealed, and only seat four comfortably?), it was a lovely afternoon. (On the way back, we strategically avoided getting into the same car as an elderly Italian man who had breath we could smell six feet away. Who wants to end an afternoon out smelling like someone else’s half-digested lunch?)

The lighting and weather were so picturesque this afternoon, I couldn’t resist coming straight home to post these. Pearce made the most incredible pasta for dinner (tomato sauce with garlic, basil, zucchini, hot pepper and capers) while I geeked out for an hour getting everything up to snuff. Though honestly, I barely touched the photos of the city — I really didn’t have to!

I’m not sure why I like this next one — I think it’s the lighting, and the clarity of Pearce’s hand on the far right.

All the credit goes to Pearce for this last one — it’s so unusual for me to have photos of myself (and probably a relief for him to get out of my camera’s line of sight for a few minutes, though it never lasts long!). Thanks, amour!

And the agenda for the evening — Barney’s Version and a potential wine run. Camera away, laptop closed, here we go!

item.title: Man vs. Guilt
item.dc:creator: dadtheidiot
item.description: I am a guilty person by nature.  It may not be apparent by reading this blog, but I apologize to people in my head for thoughts I haven’t even finished having.  That is not a joke.  I also regularly get stopped in the middle of a multi-minute disclaimer before speaking my mind.  Put me in the [...]
item.content:encoded:
I am a guilty person by nature.  It may not be apparent by reading this blog, but I apologize to people in my head for thoughts I haven’t even finished having.  That is not a joke.  I also regularly get stopped in the middle of a multi-minute disclaimer before speaking my mind.  Put me in the wrong situation and the guilt starts growing exponentially until I start throwing money at people and crying uncontrollably.  I wrote an email to a cousin I haven’t seen in 5 years yesterday, and her first words of reply were, “Oh, Ben. So much Jewish guilt in that email.”  Really.

Which is why my current situation is all the more surprising.  I don’t feel guilty at all.

“Well, why would you?” one might ask

Because, I am sitting in an easy chair, wearing a button down shirt with unwashed-for-a-week warm-up pants and black socks, a KFC Variety box on my stomach, lights off, watching Man vs. Food on T.V., writing a blog, all while Katie has the kids in Connecticut.

“But, you’re getting fatter, shouldn’t you lay off the KFC?”

Totally.  In fact this Sunday, while I was eating 2 full racks of ribs, I was thinking, “Man I should eat less KFC.”

“Maybe Man vs. Food is not a good show for you to watch.”

The Nanny is not a good show for me to watch.  It’s terrible.

"The Nanny" is worse than watching a hamburger

Anyway, the point is that I’m not feeling guilty in the slightest and I think I know why; I’m in my thirties, I have 3 kids, I have a wife who loves me (jokes on her!), I work moderately hard and I like KFC.  This is a very cool time in my life where I’m psyched about what I have, AND I’m willing to accept my reality.

When we’re first born we have no concept of reality.  Poop in your pants?  Check.  Crying for no reason? Check.  You’re a baby and you’re living the high-life.

Then, between 2 and 25 years-old we go through this magical period in our lives, where we have a hard time accepting reality.  You’re three feet tall and can climb like a you-know-what.  You just stood on a rocking chair and fell off, requiring six stitches in your chin.  The only logical solution?  Try it again… with roller-skates.  As a twenty-four year-old you do the same thing, but you’re probably taller.

Then there’s this ridiculous period between 25 and 27: the ultimate in mind and body synchronization.  It is not unheard of for a 26 year-old to learn computer-programming, lose 10-20lbs, run a marathon, eat unheard of amounts of food, drink several cases of beer, add 837 friends on facebook and have sex, during lunch.  As Charlie Sheen would say: “Winning”

Charlie Sheen also said this: “Duh! So, we’re asking you now, what are some of your favorite lines that this warlock brain produced?”

Good point Chuck.

Then as our twenties end we begin to realize that we’re peering over the physical hill.

Now, before I start getting tons of emails from you geriatric 40-60 year-olds, I’m not talking about mental peaks, just physical.  I’m glad 60 is the new 40 and you all have your slick cell-phones and know how to Skype with your great-great-grand-kids, but besides Harrison Ford, I have never seen a 50 year-old jump.

Right before 30 we start noticing that the ol’ metabolism is slowing down and the ol’ appetite might be picking up a bit.  We start saying, “I need to diet”, “I need to go for a run”, “I need to not be hung over for 6 days after having a glass of Chablis”.

Then something magical happens: we continue growing mentally.  We might pick up a spouse or a hobby and realize that life is a lot more than rock-hard abs, sex, partying, eating whatever we want, and roller-skating on rocking-chairs.

Over the past month I have blown out my knee running, playing with the kids, walking up stairs, talking with the landscaper, eating potato salad, and imagining someone blowing out their knee.  If I challenged my grandfather to a test of physical abilities, it would end with both of us falling asleep in front of C-SPAN.

But you know what? I’m not feeling guilty.  I have a friend who says “don’t push the river”, and he’s right, I’m not even sure I can swim anymore.

I’m underselling myself on purpose, but here’s the deal.  Every morning I wake up and have some aspiration that I’m gonna start running again.  I believe that somehow I’m going to start watching what I eat.  I am currently signed up as the captain for an ActiveForLife team at work (and if any of my team members are reading this, I… um… am completely kidding). But then, sometime after having my 9th cup of coffee, I realize, “uh oh, I’m not getting any more awake”, and by the time I’ve finished eating lunch, well, let’s just say you don’t want to check if I’ve unbuttoned my pants.  I’m not that much older, but suddenly my baseline is what a 25 year-old feels like after getting hit by an asteriod.

Honestly, I started running recently and at times it’s been pretty successful, and if it wasn’t 108F outside I’d be doing it right now.  But I don’t need to, I’m going to try again tomorrow and I might be successful or I might not.  I’m accepting that instead of running, sometimes this is going to happen:

Can't...reach...keyboard...

I’m gonna keep doing what I do and not feel guilty for it… except that part about the geriatric 40 year-olds… which was a little mean… probably too mean…  sorry about that… seriously… really sorry… I’m not crying… IT’S DIRT IN MY EYE!…  GO AWAY! I DON’T HAVE ANY MONEY!…

item.title: Cowboys and Aliens Review
item.dc:creator: Mike.M
item.description: I knew of Cowboys and Aliens a few years ago when it came out as a comic book and the movie rights were picked up. Unfortunately, I never read the comic, so that’s where my familiarity ends. Cowboys and Aliens takes some familiar story ideas and uses its premise to turn it all upside down. [...]
item.content:encoded:
I knew of Cowboys and Aliens a few years ago when it came out as a comic book and the movie rights were picked up. Unfortunately, I never read the comic, so that’s where my familiarity ends.

Cowboys and Aliens takes some familiar story ideas and uses its premise to turn it all upside down. The protagonist, Jake Lonergan, played by Daniel Craig, wakes up in the middle of the desert with a picture of a beautiful woman, a futuristic looking shackle on his wrist, no boots, and no memories. He wanders into Absolution, the prototypical down-on-its-luck town that is held hostage by the evil men who rule it with an iron fist. The townsfolk are too few and too scared to stand up for themselves. The man who’s in charge of the evil men, including his imbecile son, Percy, is none other than Harrison Ford as Colonel Dolarhyde, the most ruthless rancher in the west and former Army Colonel.

No sooner does Jake meet up with the town preacher who mends his wounds does he run into Percy shooting up the town and picking on townsfolk. As you may have seen in countless other movies, the brooding Jake can’t stand for it, so he takes matters into his own hands. Percy is the classic bully who can’t face off with someone tougher than he is, so in trying to show his toughness, he shoots a deputy which lands him in jail. The sheriff also happens to recognize Jake as an outlaw on a wanted poster. Time for the sheriff to have a talk with old Jake at the saloon.

Jake is approached by Ella, Olivia Wilde, an enigmatic, drop dead gorgeous woman who seems to know something about him, but he doesn’t know anything about, well, anything. This is about the time the sheriff shows up with his men and all hell breaks loose. Jake beats the crap out of them, but is waylaid by Ella and ends up in jail, with Percy. Now Percy’s dad has to come “rescue” him and it just so happens that the last job Jake did as an outlaw was stealing the Colonel’s gold. So they ride in at night as the stagecoach is about ready to take the prisoners to Santa Fe to face the judge.

This is where the raiders show up and attack the town. Only this is also where the story twists and the titular Aliens arrive. They raid the town in these flying machines destroying everything and stealing the people for who knows what. As if things weren’t bad enough in the town of Absolution. They even take Percy, the Colonel’s son.

Jake and the Colonel must put aside their differences and work together. The town must gather its courage and ride behind them to find this threat and hopefully, rescue their people.

These are themes done over and over, especially in westerns, but the story is crafted very well and the acting from both the big names and the character actors is so well done, you won’t mind that you’ve likely seen this story so many times in the past.

Daniel Craig does a pretty good job as Jake. He isn’t spectacular, but he doesn’t hold the movie back either. Jake is the mysterious brooding character who fortunately doesn’t stay that way throughout the entirety of the movie. He does grow out of his one dimension. It may take a while, but he gets there.

Harrison Ford as Colonel Woodrow Dolarhyde is the highlight of the film and I think it’s one of his best roles I’ve ever seen. Ford is an iconic action hero thanks to the Star Wars and Indiana Jones movies. He nails the curmudgeonly Colonel on the head. He’s not entirely evil though as there are scenes displaying his sensitive side to ones he cares about, but doesn’t show it.

Olivia Wilde. What can I say? She’s beautiful and capable. I thought she was especially good in Tron Legacy. Her role in this is a little more vanilla, but her character’s turn in all of the events is a nice twist that manages to bring the final part of the movie together when she must aid the humans in defeating the “demons” as they believe them to be.

Let us not forget the aliens in all of this. They spend their time in dark tunnels or hunting at night, though for some reason even though they apparently don’t see well during the day, they don’t have much of a problem laying waste to cowboys and indians alike. I can’t say that they look remarkable and they’re practically invincible to the humans’ weapons. Good thing they have the equalizer in Jake’s wrist.

Clocking in at almost two hours, the typical runtime for most movies, I’d say it was paced pretty well. There is the matter of fitting in a love interest with Ella not long after the death of the previous love interest, but I guess in fairness, Jake doesn’t really remember much of that relationship until much later. There is plenty of action starting with the human side of things then moving onto the aliens. There is plenty of comic relief, but not to the extreme bonehead side of things. I think the levity may actually surprise you at moments. Thanks much in part to the acting.

I would be remiss in not mentioning the number of character actors you’ll see from various other movies and television shows who perform admirably alongside the star power of Craig, Ford, and Wilde.

Clancy Brown plays the role of Preacher Meachem. He sees the good in people, including Jake. You’d know him from so many different roles throughout the years. My favorite has to be as Brother Justin in Carnivale, but he also plays Sgt. Zim in Starship Troopers, Captain Hadley in Shawshank Redemption and, I bet you had no idea about this, Mr. Krabs in Spongebob Squarepants.Sam Rockwell is the cowardly saloon owner known as Doc. Apparently he is a doctor, or pretends well enough to be one… You’d recognize Rockwell as Justin Hammer from Iron Man 2 most recently. Remember Guy Fleegman from Galaxy Quest? Yep, that’s him.

Keith Carradine has been around forever and done probably a million things. I wish Wild Bill Hickock lasted a bit longer in Deadwood.

I wouldn’t blame you if you didn’t know who Toby Huss was, because I don’t know the name. He has a small part in Cowboys and Aliens. Yet, if you’re a fan of Carnivale, you’d know him as Stumpy, barker for the family cootch show and pimp of his wife when need be.

Walter Goggins is another name I don’t know. Apparently he was in The Shield among other things. He’s got a megawatt smile though and he practically reprises his goofball cowboy role from Shanghai Noon.

The 3D graphics in the movie didn’t really blow me away. There are some very cool sets such as scenes showing the humans captive in the alien compound. Other than that, the finale is spectacular whereas the rest is pretty standard 3D stuff you’d see in movies or television shows nowadays, flying ships, aliens and the sort.

Cowboys and Aliens is not a movie that lives off of its 3D graphics and its aliens. It lives through the believable and likable characters. If Jake and the Colonel don’t become approachable “humans” by the end, then I don’t think the movie would’ve clicked. No one really outshines anyone. Yes, this film would’ve likely been fantastic as a western, but we’ve seen plenty of westerns of this ilk.

Cowboys and Aliens does enough with the alien invasion aspect to set it apart and not make it a hokey western or worse yet, a hokey comic book movie. That is a justice in itself.

Cowboys and Aliens earns its respectable 4 out of 5 stars.

item.title: Crawfish Festival
item.dc:creator: Dinah
item.description: Highlights: Cajun and Zydeco music, crawfish, and other Louisiana-style foods On the last weekend of July at Long Beach, crawfish (a.k.a. crayfish, crawdad, or mud bug) was the star.  The weekend was filled with steaming crawfish, other New Orleans inspired foods, and Cajun and Zydeco music.  For 18 years, the festival continues to feast and party Louisiana style.  Over [...]

item.title: Homemade Crayons
item.dc:creator: Ashley Andrews
item.description: By: Robin Ruerhrwein This is a tutorial that I posted on my personal blog, Masshole Mommy, last week, but I was so proud of my accomplishment – that I wanted to share it here, too. Let me start by saying that I don’t consider myself to be a crafty sort of mom. I just don’t [...]
item.content:encoded:
By: Robin Ruerhrwein

This is a tutorial that I posted on my personal blog, Masshole Mommy, last week, but I was so proud of my accomplishment – that I wanted to share it here, too.

Let me start by saying that I don’t consider myself to be a crafty sort of mom. I just don’t have what it takes to pull it off as much as I wish I did. I do a lot of scrapbooking, though, and not to toot my own horn, but I think I do a pretty good job at them.  That is pretty much the extent of my crafting abilities, though.  However, as I started planning my boys Lego themed birthday party, which I’m having in August, I realized that I’d either have to shell out a lot of cash for Lego supplies – or just make them myself.  So my first attempt at being crafty was to make Lego shaped crayons that I plan on putting into the kids goody bags.

So, I went onto Ebay and ordered these silicone ice cube trays:

As you can see one tray consists of little Lego bricks and the other are Lego Minifigure shaped (and yes, they are the exact same height as a real Lego Minifigure).  They were only a couple of bucks apiece and compared to buying premade Lego shaped crayons (on Ebay or similar sites), I saved a bundle.

I picked up a bunch of packs of crayons for .24 cents each while I was at Walmart and those are what I used to make the Lego shaped crayons.

Next I spent what felt like forever some time peeling all of them.

After they were all peeled, I broke them into little pieces and filled the molds:

Next I put them into the microwave (12 minutes for the Minifigures and 15 minutes for the Lego bricks) until all the crayons were melted:

Once the wax was fully melted, I put the trays of melted wax into the fridge for about ten minutes and voila:

These were so inexpensive and easy to make & I really was proud that they turned out so well. What do you think?


Filed under: Activities, Bargains, Events, Family, Mommy Advice, Parenting Advice, Robin Ruehrwein Tagged: brockton hospital, brockton hospital Signature Moms blog, hospital blog, hospital mommy blog, mommy blog, mommy blogger, robin ruehrwein, signature healthcare, signature mommy blog, signature moms

item.title: Museum of Flight
item.dc:creator: pubster
item.description: If you like things that fly with people in them, you have to check out the Museum of Flight near the Boeing Air Field in South Seattle. It’s a little Boeing-centric, but other aviation companies and aviators are given space as well, and it’s celebration of the beauty of aircraft is unparallelled. My favourites are [...]
